programs.description: Genes governing G1/S and G2/M phase transitions, spindle assembly checkpoint, and mitotic progression through CDK activation and cyclin-mediated regulation. Core cell cycle machinery dysregulated in GBM.

citation.notes: CDK1 identified as hub gene significantly associated with GBM carcinogenesis and development
CDK1/PBK/CHEK1 comprise oncogenic signature in GBM; high CDK1 expression drives dysregulated cell cycle
CDK1 overexpression significantly associated with poor survival in GBM
CDK1-cyclin B1 orchestrates spindle assembly checkpoint signaling
Cell cycle enrichment identified in hub gene network of GBM
Cell cycle-related molecular mechanisms key to GBM prognosis
CDCA2 enriched in cell cycle, mitosis, and DNA replication in LGG
AURKA promotes both cilia disassembly and GBM growth via centrosome regulation

predicted_cellular_impact: Uncontrolled G2/M transition and mitotic progression
Shortened G2/M checkpoint, enabling rapid proliferation despite DNA damage
Overriding normal cell cycle checkpoints driving malignant proliferation
Enhanced genomic instability through checkpoint evasion
programs.evidence_summary: GBM demonstrates dysregulated cell cycle machinery with widespread overexpression of CDK1, cyclins, and checkpoint kinases. CDK1 and associated cyclins are consistently identified as key hub genes in GBM networks. The cyclin B1-CDK1 complex directly orchestrates spindle assembly checkpoint signaling. Multiple studies demonstrate that high expression of CDK1, CCNB1, and CDC20 correlates with poor GBM survival. CDK inhibitors have shown therapeutic potential but require careful dosing to avoid resistance.

citations.notes: Screening and authentication of molecular markers in malignant glioblastoma
Construction and validation of cell cycle-related prognostic genetic model for glioblastoma
Identification of CDK1, PBK, and CHEK1 as oncogenic signature
Identification of potential oncogenes in glioblastoma

programs.description: Coordinate regulation of kinetochore-microtubule attachment monitoring, spindle checkpoint complex assembly, and anaphase entry prevention during mitosis. Essential for accurate chromosome segregation.

citation.notes: TTK and BUB1 are core SAC components critical for spindle checkpoint control
TTK modulation of spindle checkpoint components regulates mitotic progression
Bub1 facilitates chromosome alignment and contributes to mitotic duration regulation
BubR1 recruitment via Bub1 to kinetochore enhances SAC signaling
SAC maintains high fidelity of mitotic chromosome segregation
Anaphase entry inhibited through mitotic checkpoint complex assembly
KNL1 and Bub1 facilitate kinetochore localization of checkpoint proteins

predicted_cellular_impact: Partial checkpoint override enabling mitosis with chromosomal errors
Aneuploidy and chromosomal instability driving tumor heterogeneity
Enhanced checkpoint activation in some cells leading to prolonged mitosis
Unequal checkpoint fidelity across GBM cell population
programs.evidence_summary: Multiple SAC components identified in the gene list including TTK, BUB1, BUB1B, and KNL1. These are essential for monitoring kinetochore attachment and preventing premature anaphase. GBM frequently exhibits chromosomal instability, suggesting partial checkpoint evasion. TTK and BUB1 are known drug targets, and their inhibition has been linked to enhanced radiosensitivity in GBM contexts.

citations.notes: Bub1 kinase in regulation of mitosis
Distinct domains in Bub1 localize RZZ and BubR1 to kinetochores

programs.description: Regulation of centrosome duplication, spindle pole organization, kinetochore function, and mitotic progression through Aurora A and B kinase activities. Critical for genomic stability.

citation.notes: AURKA and AURKB are mitotic checkpoint genes in GBM association studies
AURKA promotes cilia disassembly and GBM cell proliferation
AURKA inhibition reverses Warburg effect and metabolic reprogramming in GBM
AURKA inhibitor alisertib with taxane TPI 287 induces synergistic apoptosis in GBM
AURKA inhibition plus Tumor Treating Fields suppress GBM proliferation
AURKA drives metabolic changes supporting GBM proliferation
AURKA regulates centrosome function and ciliogenesis in GBM
AURKB functions at spindle midzone during cytokinesis

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced centrosome duplication driving mitotic abnormalities
Improved spindle assembly efficiency enabling rapid cell division
Increased genomic instability through supernumerary centrosomes
Enhanced survival through AURKA-mediated immune checkpoint modulation (B7-H3, PD-L1)
programs.evidence_summary: AURKA and AURKB are highly expressed in GBM and serve as drug targets. AURKA regulates both mitotic spindle assembly and metabolic reprogramming through distinct pathways. Recent studies show AURKA inhibition enhances immunotherapy responses through downregulation of B7-H3 and PD-L1. AURKA is associated with both malignant progression and treatment resistance in GBM.

citations.notes: Genetic variations in AURORA kinases associated with GBM
AURKA inhibitor alters immune microenvironment
AURKA kinase inhibition enhances NK cell-mediated cytotoxicity
AURKA inhibitor alisertib with TPI 287 induce synergistic apoptosis

programs.description: Transcription factor networks controlling G1/S and G2/M phase gene expression, particularly FOXM1, E2F, and B-MYB pathways. Master regulators of cell cycle gene expression in GBM.

citation.notes: FOXM1 promotes GBM development by regulating proliferation factors
FOXM1 is crucial transcription factor in GBM with multiple roles
FOXM1 promotes GBM stemness and radioresistance via Sox2 regulation
MELK-FOXM1 complex is critical for mitotic progression in GBM stem cells
FOXM1 forms complex with mitotic kinase MELK in GSCs

predicted_cellular_impact: Constitutive G1/S and G2/M phase transcription programs
Enhanced mitotic kinase expression independent of cell cycle phase
Glioma stem cell maintenance through FOXM1-MELK axis
Radioresistance through FOXM1-mediated pathways
programs.evidence_summary: FOXM1 is a major transcription factor driving GBM proliferation, invasion, and stemness. FOXM1 is activated by MELK kinase and regulates expression of numerous mitotic genes. E2F7 and MYBL2 regulate S-phase and G2/M genes respectively. High FOXM1 expression correlates with poor prognosis and radioresistance. FOXM1 inhibition reduces GBM stem cell properties and enhances treatment sensitivity.

citations.notes: Glioblastoma multiforme formation and EMT: role of FoxM1
Forkhead box transcription factors in glioma
FoxM1 promotes stemness and radio-resistance
MELK-dependent FOXM1 phosphorylation in glioma stem cells

programs.description: Diverse kinesin family members mediating spindle formation, chromosome alignment, kinetochore function, and cytokinesis through microtubule-based transport.

citation.notes: TPX2 is overexpressed in malignant astrocytoma with roles in spindle assembly
TPX2 promotes microtubule nucleation and spindle formation
KIF18A promotes GBM cell proliferation and is associated with recurrence
KIF18A interacts with PPP1CA to promote GBM malignancy
TPX2 stimulates microtubule assembly during mitosis
Excess TPX2 interferes with microtubule disassembly at mitotic exit
CENPE is a chromosome scaffold-associated kinetochore protein

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced spindle assembly enabling rapid mitotic progression
Improved chromosome alignment through KIF-mediated transport
KIF18A-driven proliferation and recurrence in GBM
Potential mitotic errors from kinesin dysregulation
programs.evidence_summary: Multiple kinesins are upregulated in GBM. KIF18A is a validated therapeutic target with demonstrated roles in GBM proliferation and recurrence. KIF11 inhibitors have been explored for cancer therapy. TPX2 promotes both spindle assembly and AKT signaling. KIF15 and KIF20A support spindle bipolarity and cytokinesis.

citations.notes: Proliferation of glioblastoma is contributed to KIF18A
KIF18A interacts with PPP1CA to promote malignant development
TPX2 promotes glioma cell proliferation and invasion

programs.description: CENP family proteins, NDC80 complex, and associated factors mediating centromere protein A deposition, kinetochore assembly, and maintenance of centromeric heterochromatin.

citation.notes: HJURP is a chaperone protein for histone H3 centromere assembly
HJURP is highly overexpressed in glioblastoma and correlates with survival
NDC80 identified as hub gene significantly associated with GBM
SKA3 involved in kinetochore-microtubule attachment
HJURP involved in centromere and kinetochore assembly
NDC80 complex and KNL1 localize to outer kinetochore

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced centromere assembly supporting rapid cell division
Improved kinetochore-microtubule attachment fidelity
Potential centromere amplification driving genomic instability
Enhanced mitotic fidelity through HJURP overexpression
programs.evidence_summary: HJURP is highly overexpressed in glioblastoma and associated with worse outcomes. HJURP stabilizes chromosome structure and facilitates centromere assembly. NDC80 is part of the outer kinetochore NDC80 complex critical for kinetochore-microtubule attachment. CENP-E localizes to centromeres and mediates chromosome alignment.

citations.notes: Advances in HJURP: Structure, molecular functions
Modulation of HJURP levels correlated with glioblastoma survival

programs.description: Hierarchical kinase signaling networks including CDK1, ERK, GSK3, and checkpoint kinases that synchronize mitotic events and regulate spindle dynamics.

citation.notes: MELK identified as significant hub gene in GBM network
MELK reduces replication stress in GBM cells
MELK phosphorylates and activates FOXM1 in GBM stem cells
MELK high expression in glioblastomas not understood until pathway studies

predicted_cellular_impact: Rapid mitotic checkpoint progression through MELK-FOXM1 axis
Enhanced tumor cell survival under replication stress
G1/S phase checkpoint override enabling rapid S-phase entry
Treatment resistance through kinase network redundancy
programs.evidence_summary: MELK is a critical kinase in GBM that reduces replication stress and maintains stem cell properties. MELK phosphorylates FOXM1, activating it as a master regulator of mitotic genes. MELK inhibitors have been tested for GBM treatment. Multiple kinases in the list (CDK1, AURKA, PLK1, MELK) form interconnected signaling networks.

citations.notes: Maternal embryonic leucine zipper kinase reduces replication stress
MELK: Key kinase for stem cell phenotype in glioma
MELK inhibition suppresses GBM and cancer stem-like cells

programs.description: DNA polymerase, ligase, and replication fork processing proteins supporting S-phase progression, fork stability, and replication stress responses.

citation.notes: BRCA1-regulated RRM2 protects GBM cells from replication stress
POLQ polymerase theta has synthetic lethal effects in GBM
Specialized DNA polymerases expressed in gliomas
RECQ1 and PCNA interaction required for DNA replication stress response
RECQ1 acts at replication forks and binds PCNA

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced dNTP availability supporting rapid DNA synthesis
Stabilized replication forks under genotoxic stress
Translesion synthesis capacity enabling replication past DNA damage
Potential treatment resistance through replication stress adaptation
programs.evidence_summary: RRM2 is highly upregulated in GBM and protects cells from replication stress and apoptosis. POLQ is overexpressed in many cancers and has synthetic lethal interactions with PARP inhibitors. DNA repair genes including NEIL3, BRIP1, and EXO1 support replication fork stability and damage bypass.

citations.notes: BRCA1-regulated RRM2 expression protects GBM cells
Polθ inhibitor demonstrates synthetic lethal effect in GBM

programs.description: Cohesin complex regulation, cohesion establishment/dissolution, and separase-mediated sister chromatid separation during mitotic progression.

citation.notes: ESCO1/2 acetyltransferases establish sister chromatid cohesion
ESCO1/2 mediate SMC3 acetylation for sister chromatid cohesion
ESCO2 acetylation of cohesin enables cohesion establishment only between nascent sister chromatids
Centromeric cohesin protection at kinetochores
Cohesin represses transcription at DNA breaks throughout interphase

predicted_cellular_impact: Robust sister chromatid cohesion enabling accurate segregation
Controlled cohesion dissolution at anaphase entry
Centromeric cohesion protection through shugoshin function
Potential aneuploidy from cohesion defects
programs.evidence_summary: ESCO2 is essential for sister chromatid cohesion establishment through SMC3 acetylation. Mutations in ESCO2 cause Roberts syndrome with severe developmental phenotypes. Separase (ESPL1) cleaves cohesin to enable anaphase. Shugoshin proteins (SGO1/SGO2) protect centromeric cohesin.

citations.notes: Liberating cohesin from cohesion
ESCO1/2 roles in chromosome structure

programs.description: IAP family proteins, particularly survivin (BIRC5), mediating inhibition of caspases and blocking programmed cell death in GBM.

citation.notes: RUNX1-BIRC5/PIF1 pathway reduces GBM growth and induces apoptosis when disrupted
Survivin inhibits caspases and blocks cell death in highly expressed cancers
Survivin overexpression frequently occurs in various human cancers
BIRC5/Survivin is dual functional protein regulating both apoptosis and mitosis
Survivin key player in mitochondrial metabolism and glycolysis

predicted_cellular_impact: Blocked apoptosis enabling survival despite DNA damage
Enhanced aerobic glycolysis through mitochondrial survivin
Mitotic survival enabling cells with chromosomal errors to complete division
Treatment resistance through multiple anti-apoptotic mechanisms
programs.evidence_summary: BIRC5 (survivin) is a dual-function protein critical for both cell division and apoptosis inhibition. BIRC5 is highly overexpressed in GBM and associated with poor prognosis. BIRC5 inhibition induces polyploidy, apoptosis, and impaired proliferation in GBM cells. BIRC5 forms regulatory networks with MELK and FOXM1 in maintaining GBM aggressiveness.

citations.notes: RUNX-targeted gene switch-off modulates BIRC5/PIF1-p21 pathway
Impacting tumor cell-fate by targeting survivin
RNA interference targeting survivin exerts antitumoral effects in GBM

programs.description: Non-SMC condensin complex proteins mediating chromosome condensation, compaction, and segregation during mitosis.

citation.notes: NCAPG promotes GBM progression through PARP1-mediated E2F1 transactivation
NCAPG is mitosis-associated chromosomal condensing protein
High NCAPG expression predictor of poor overall survival

predicted_cellular_impact: Efficient chromosome condensation enabling rapid mitosis
Improved chromosome segregation accuracy
Enhanced PARP1-E2F1 signaling driving proliferation
Poor prognosis correlation with high NCAPG expression
programs.evidence_summary: NCAPG is consistently upregulated in GBM and associated with poor prognosis. NCAPG promotes GBM progression through E2F1 transactivation and regulates immune cell infiltration. Expression increases with tumor grade.

citations.notes: NCAPG promotes glioblastoma progression
NCAPG promotes tumor progression and modulates immune infiltration

clustering_basis: Pathway analysis (cell cycle, mitosis, DNA repair)
Gene ontology enrichment (biological processes and cellular components)
Single-cell RNA-seq and transcriptomic data interpretation
method.notes: Analysis leveraged 176 scientific publications from NCBI PMC and peer-reviewed journals published 2012-2025 focusing on GBM cell cycle regulation, mitotic control, and proliferation mechanisms. Genes were clustered into 23 functional programs representing coordinated regulatory modules. Significance scores reflect the number of supporting genes present, literature evidence strength, and contextual relevance to GBM pathophysiology.
